*Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Inc.raw_text: *Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Incentives, Inc.*, 398 Mass. 854, 859 (1986).
*Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Inc.proposition: At all times relevant hereto, the employees, agents, and staff members of Defendant were acting within the course and scope of their employment and/or agency with Defendant, and Defendant is vicariously liable for their acts and omissions under the doctrine of respondeat superior. See *Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Incentives, Inc.*, 398 Mass. 854, 859 (1986).
*Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Inc.case_name: Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Incentives, Inc.
*Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Inc.support_reasoning: The case does address when an employer is vicariously liable for an employee’s acts under a scope-of-employment analysis and explicitly uses respondeat superior concepts. However, it does not state the broad factual proposition that, “At all times relevant hereto, the employees, agents, and staff members of Defendant were acting within the course and scope of their employment.” Instead, it applies scope-of-employment factors to a specific employee (Joseph) and concludes his conduct was within the scope of employment; it is thus authority for the legal test for scope of employment and vicarious liability, not for the quoted factual assertion about all employees in a given case.
*Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Inc.relevant_excerpt: “We agree that Wang cannot be held liable under G. L. c. 93A for the conduct of an employee acting outside the scope of his employment. … To determine whether an employee’s conduct is within the scope of his employment for purposes of employer liability under G. L. c. 93A, we may appropriately be guided by a consideration of the factors relevant to scope of employment determinations bearing on the imposition of vicarious liability on employers for the tortious conduct of their employees.”

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A..proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Brockton Division of the District Court Department because the causes of action arise from events that occurred in Brockton, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court. See G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2..proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the incident giving rise to this claim occurred at Defendant’s premises located at 123 Community Center Way, Brockton, MA 02302, within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court. See G.L. c. 223, § 2.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 143\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity owes a duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 143–44 (2006); *Hebert v. Enos*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 817, 820–21 (2004).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 143\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states the general Massachusetts tort principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, with foreseeability of harm as a precondition. The court’s duty analysis is explicit, general, and not limited to the specific firearm-storage facts, so it properly supports the cited proposition that under Massachusetts law there is a duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 143\u201.relevant_excerpt: "We have recognized that '[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.' See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. ... Consequently, with some important exceptions, 'a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct.'"

*Hebert v. Enos*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 817,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity owes a duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 143–44 (2006); *Hebert v. Enos*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 817, 820–21 (2004).
*Hebert v. Enos*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 817,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not explicitly restate a broad, general duty of reasonable care, but it proceeds on the assumption that the defendant owed such a duty and focuses its analysis on the foreseeability component of negligence (duty/proximate cause). The court applies the standard of “care that was reasonable in the circumstances” and analyzes whether the plaintiff’s injury was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s conduct. This is consistent with, and implicitly supports, the proposition that Massachusetts law imposes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm, even though the case ultimately finds the harm here not reasonably foreseeable.
*Hebert v. Enos*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 817,.relevant_excerpt: “Summary judgment is still appropriate, however, if a plaintiff has no reasonable expectation of proving that ‘the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.’ … We say that ‘[o]ne is bound to anticipate and provide against what usually happens and what is likely to happen, but is not bound in like manner to guard against what is . . . only remotely and slightly probable.’ … We conclude that the motion judge held the defendant to the ‘proper standard of care [which] is . . . the usual one of traditional negligence theory: “to exercise care that was reasonable in the circumstances.”’

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: A landowner and operator of a facility such as Defendant owes a duty to lawful visitors, including children in its care, to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe and to protect them against reasonably foreseeable risks of harm. See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973); *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 742 (1995).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the seminal Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners/occupiers to lawful visitors. While the provided excerpt is from a concurrence and focuses on trespassers, the majority at 363 Mass. 707 clearly articulates that occupiers owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to keep premises reasonably safe from foreseeable harm. The proposition’s reference to lawful visitors (including children in care) is consistent with that general duty, though children are not specifically discussed in the quoted concurrence.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: (From the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707) [Paraphrased as the exact passage is not in the excerpt provided]: The court holds that an occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, thereby abolishing the invitee–licensee distinction in determining the measure of responsibility.

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: A landowner and operator of a facility such as Defendant owes a duty to lawful visitors, including children in its care, to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe and to protect them against reasonably foreseeable risks of harm. See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973); *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 742 (1995).
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the modern Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors and describes that duty as including maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers. The case then applies that general duty framework to decide that Westwood had no additional duty to alter the adjacent state highway. Thus, while the holding is narrower, the case clearly affirms the general duty proposition for lawful visitors, which can include children.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

*Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8, 12\u20.proposition: An organization that undertakes the supervision and care of children, including an after-school program and community center, owes a heightened duty of reasonable care in supervising those children and protecting them from unreasonable risks of physical harm, including harm from other children’s dangerous conduct that is known or reasonably foreseeable. See *Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8, 12–13 (1991) (duty to protect child from foreseeable harm); *Commonwealth v. Welansky*, 316 Mass. 383, 397 (1944) (duty arises from control of premises and patron safety).
*Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8, 12\u20.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts a heightened duty of reasonable care owed by an organization (or caretaker) supervising children, including a duty to protect them from foreseeable harm caused by other children. Wallace v. Wilson holds the opposite in a closely analogous context: it explicitly refuses to impose a duty on a parent hosting a teen party to supervise or control minors’ drinking to protect third parties from ensuing harm, whether the harm is an auto accident (Langemann) or assault and battery (this case). The decision is about *no duty* in these circumstances, not about a heightened duty of reasonable care, so citing it for that proposition is inaccurate and contrary to its holding.
*Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8, 12\u20.relevant_excerpt: “We continue to adhere to the rule expressed in Langemann, and we think that that rule should apply here. It should make no difference that the plaintiffs, instead of being automobile accident victims, are victims of assault and battery, nor should it make a difference that the parent is at home when and where the party takes place, instead of being away.… We conclude that summary judgment for the defendant was correctly ordered in both cases.”

*Commonwealth v. Welansky*, 316 Mass. 38.proposition: An organization that undertakes the supervision and care of children, including an after-school program and community center, owes a heightened duty of reasonable care in supervising those children and protecting them from unreasonable risks of physical harm, including harm from other children’s dangerous conduct that is known or reasonably foreseeable. See *Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8, 12–13 (1991) (duty to protect child from foreseeable harm); *Commonwealth v. Welansky*, 316 Mass. 383, 397 (1944) (duty arises from control of premises and patron safety).
*Commonwealth v. Welansky*, 316 Mass. 38.support_reasoning: Welansky concerns a nightclub owner’s criminal liability for manslaughter based on wanton or reckless disregard of patron safety arising from his control of premises open to the public. It does not involve children, after‑school programs, or any articulation of a “heightened” duty of care, nor does it address protection from other children’s conduct. The case is relevant only for the general idea that a proprietor who controls premises and invites the public owes a duty of reasonable care for patron safety; it does not substantively support the specific, heightened-duty proposition described.
*Commonwealth v. Welansky*, 316 Mass. 38.relevant_excerpt: “But where, as in the present case, there is a duty of care for the safety of business visitors invited to premises which the defendant controls, wanton or reckless conduct may consist of intentional failure to take such care in disregard of the probable harmful consequences to them or of their right to care.” (316 Mass. at 397)

*Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316,.proposition: Defendant, having voluntarily undertaken to supervise and care for J.J. in its after-school program, owed a duty to exercise reasonable care in supervising him and other children in the gym, in maintaining adequate staffing, and in responding appropriately to known dangerous conduct. See *Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316, 321–22 (2002) (duty from voluntary undertaking); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47, 50–54 (1983) (duty to take reasonable measures to protect students from foreseeable harm).
*Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316,.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Cottam only for the general principle that a duty can arise from a voluntary undertaking. In section 3, the SJC expressly reaffirms that Massachusetts recognizes liability where a defendant voluntarily assumes a duty and must then perform it with due care, quoting Restatement (Second) of Torts § 323 and prior Massachusetts cases. Although the facts involve a pharmacy’s warnings rather than supervision of children, the opinion clearly establishes the voluntary-undertaking duty principle relied on in the proposition.
*Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316,.relevant_excerpt: “A pharmacy, like any other person or entity, may voluntarily assume a duty that would not otherwise be imposed on it… Massachusetts recognizes that ‘a duty voluntarily assumed must be performed with due care,’ and we have approved the principles pertaining to voluntary assumption of a duty as set forth in the Restatement (Second) of Torts § 323 (1965). … ‘If a person voluntarily assumes a duty or undertakes to render services to another that should have been seen as necessary for her protection, that person may be liable for harm caused because of the negligent performance of his undertaking.’”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: Defendant, having voluntarily undertaken to supervise and care for J.J. in its after-school program, owed a duty to exercise reasonable care in supervising him and other children in the gym, in maintaining adequate staffing, and in responding appropriately to known dangerous conduct. See *Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316, 321–22 (2002) (duty from voluntary undertaking); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47, 50–54 (1983) (duty to take reasonable measures to protect students from foreseeable harm).
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: Even though this is a dissent excerpt focused on proximate cause, Mullins as a whole is well-known Massachusetts authority recognizing that a college has a duty to use reasonable care to protect its resident students from foreseeable criminal acts, including by taking reasonable security measures. That general duty to protect students from foreseeable harm is analogous to, and supports, the proposition that a defendant who undertakes supervision and care (here, of children in an after-school program) owes a duty to exercise reasonable care in supervision, staffing, and protective responses. This excerpt itself does not restate the duty rule, but it implicitly accepts the majority’s recognition of such a duty and disputes only causation.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving that the defendant[] took a risk with respect to the plaintiffs safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969). The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes.

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care owed under Massachusetts law and constituted negligence. See *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000) (negligence is failure to act as an ordinary prudent person under the circumstances); *Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 262, 267 (1986).
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.support_reasoning: The opinion in Glidden v. Maglio concerns whether plaintiffs produced sufficient evidence of causation to survive summary judgment on negligence and statutory claims. It does not articulate the general definition of negligence as “failure to act as an ordinary prudent person under the circumstances,” nor does it set out or discuss the standard of care in those terms. The case is therefore not proper authority for the quoted general negligence standard, even though it involves negligence claims.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care owed under Massachusetts law and constituted negligence. See *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000) (negligence is failure to act as an ordinary prudent person under the circumstances); *Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 262, 267 (1986).
*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely defines negligence in terms of the reasonable person standard and criticizes the trial judge for not articulating that standard clearly. The court states that negligence is the failure to exercise the degree of care a reasonable person would under the circumstances, which matches the proposition’s description of Massachusetts negligence law. Thus, Morgan v. Lalumiere is properly cited as authority for that standard of care formulation.
*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Negligence is the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonable person would exercise in the circumstances. Of course, a judge may elaborate upon that definition so long as what he says is consistent with the correct definition of negligence. Without at least some minimal reference to the reasonable person standard and to the attendant circumstances, however, an instruction does not adequately convey the meaning of negligence.

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996).
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: The conduct of the older children in tackling J.J. was a natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s failure to supervise and failure to respond to the known dangerous rough play, and does not constitute a superseding cause that would relieve Defendant of liability. See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996); *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 440, 445–46 (2007).
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Poskus concerns foreseeability and causation in the context of keys left in ignitions and expressly concludes that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by defendant’s negligence. That is the opposite of the proposition claimed, which asserts that subsequent wrongful conduct (tackling J.J.) was a natural and probable consequence of the defendant’s negligence and not a superseding cause. Poskus, at least in this excerpt, does not endorse that principle and instead finds the harm not reasonably foreseeable, thereby not supporting the cited proposition.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.raw_text: *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 440, 445–46 (2007).
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: The conduct of the older children in tackling J.J. was a natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s failure to supervise and failure to respond to the known dangerous rough play, and does not constitute a superseding cause that would relieve Defendant of liability. See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996); *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 440, 445–46 (2007).
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: This opinion is a domestic relations/child support contempt decision and does not involve negligence, foreseeability, rough play, or superseding/intervening causes. There is no discussion of whether third-party conduct is a natural and probable consequence of a defendant’s failure to supervise or whether such conduct constitutes a superseding cause. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the tort proposition stated and appears to be a miscitation (likely intending another Jesionek case).
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: We think, based on the foregoing authorities, that (except in the case of educational support) the trial judge is not required to wait until a child nears the end of his or her minority to make an order for general support that continues until a child is emancipated (as defined by the statutory framework), by virtue of continued dependency on and domicile with a custodial parent.

*Aspen v. Boston*, 398 Mass. 32, 34 (198.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about J.J.’s injuries and the resulting economic and non-economic damages to Plaintiff and his minor child. See *Aspen v. Boston*, 398 Mass. 32, 34 (1986).
*Aspen v. Boston*, 398 Mass. 32, 34 (198.support_reasoning: Aspen v. Boston is a products-liability/warranty case addressing foreseeability of product use and the plaintiff’s unreasonable use/assumption-of-risk type defense. It does not set out or apply a general negligence or causation standard such as whether a defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing a plaintiff’s injuries and damages. The case therefore does not provide authority for the causation proposition stated and is being cited out of context for that purpose.
*Aspen v. Boston*, 398 Mass. 32, 34 (198.relevant_excerpt: “A warranty of merchantability that goods ‘are fit for the ordinary purposes for which such goods are used’ is implied in a contract for their sale… Thus, to prove his case a plaintiff asserting a personal injury claim based on a breach of an implied warranty of merchantability must prove that at the time of his injury he was using the product in a manner that the defendant seller, manufacturer, or distributor reasonably could have foreseen… Quite apart from this element of a plaintiff’s claim is a defendant’s affirmative defense that the plaintiff is barred from recovery because… [of] his conduct.”

*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for all losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and emotional distress. See *Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540, 548–49 (1982); *Dobos v. Driscoll*, 404 Mass. 634, 640–41 (1989).
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.support_reasoning: The cited portion of Payton does discuss recoverable harms in tort, but only in the specific context of negligent infliction of emotional distress and the need for accompanying physical harm. It does not set out a general rule that plaintiffs are entitled to compensatory damages for all losses proximately caused by negligence, nor does it enumerate medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and emotional distress as standard categories of damages. Instead, the case restricts recovery for emotional distress absent physical harm, so it is not proper authority for the broad, general damages proposition stated.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.relevant_excerpt: "If the tortious conduct and the legal causation of the harm can be satisfactorily established, there may be recovery for any injury occurring at any time after conception. Restatement (Second) of Torts § 869, Comment d (1979). We believe that '[t]he element of speculation is not present to any greater extent [here] than in the usual tort claim.' Torigian v. Watertown News Co., supra at 448-449. Accordingly, we see no reason why the particular means by which the injuries allegedly were inflicted... should require the plaintiffs 'to go through life carrying the scar of another's fault... without any compensation therefor.'"

*Dobos v. Driscoll*, 404 Mass. 634, 640\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for all losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and emotional distress. See *Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540, 548–49 (1982); *Dobos v. Driscoll*, 404 Mass. 634, 640–41 (1989).
*Dobos v. Driscoll*, 404 Mass. 634, 640\.support_reasoning: Dobos v. Driscoll is a § 1983 / governmental immunity case focused on supervisory liability and the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act. The excerpt concerns liability, immunity, and standards of culpability; it does not discuss the measure or categories of compensatory damages, such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or emotional distress. Thus, while the case may have involved such damages factually, the opinion as provided does not establish or articulate the general Massachusetts rule on recoverable compensatory damages cited in the proposition.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B,.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B, and costs as allowed by law.
